nodes.bodyText: Can you put a prominent notice right above here that the session is or isn't read-only?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2020,20 +2022,36 @@ def connect_to_cloud_db(cmd_name, *args)
   common = Common.new
   op = WbOptionsParser.new(cmd_name, args)
   op.add_option(
-    "--root",
-    ->(opts, _) { opts.root = true },
-    "Connect as root")
+    "--db-user [user]",
+    ->(opts, v) { opts.db_user = v },
+    "Optional database user to connect as, defaults to 'dev-readonly'")
   gcc = GcloudContextV2.new(op)
   op.parse.validate
   gcc.validate
+
+  if op.opts.db_user.nil?
+    op.opts.db_user = "dev-readonly"
+  end
+
   env = read_db_vars(gcc)
+  db_password = nil
+  case op.opts.db_user
+  when "dev-readonly"
+    db_password = env["DEV_READONLY_DB_PASSWORD"]
+  when "workbench"
+    db_password = env["WORKBENCH_DB_PASSWORD"]
+  when "root"
+    db_password = env["MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD"]
+  else
+    raise ArgumentError.new(
+            "invalid --db-user provided, wanted 'workbench', 'dev-readonly', or 'root', got '#{op.opts.db_user}'")
+  end
+
   CloudSqlProxyContext.new(gcc.project).run do
-    password = op.opts.root ? env["MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD"] : env["WORKBENCH_DB_PASSWORD"]
-    user = op.opts.root ? "root" : env["WORKBENCH_DB_USER"]

-      mysql --host=127.0.0.1 --port=3307 --user=#{user}
-      --database=#{env["DB_NAME"]} --password=#{password}},
-      password
+      mysql --host=127.0.0.1 --port=3307 --user=#{op.opts.db_user}

nodes.bodyText:
Maybe for a later pass, but do we have a policy about which systems we need named accounts per user for and which ones we can share? If at some point we wanted to audit who was running which statements, it would be helpful to associate these sessions with names.
Or maybe there's another way to capture that outside of mysql.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,8 @@ def write_db_creds_file(project, cdr_db_name, root_password, workbench_password)
       db_creds_file.puts "MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=#{root_password}"
       db_creds_file.puts "WORKBENCH_DB_USER=workbench"
       db_creds_file.puts "WORKBENCH_DB_PASSWORD=#{workbench_password}"
+      db_creds_file.puts "DEV_READONLY_DB_USER=dev-readonly"

nodes.bodyText:
In general we don't have a critical dependency on mysql users for auditing nor for authentication (except as defense-in-depth), since CloudSQL has its own mechanisms outside of MySQL for managing this (i.e. cloud sql proxy). The current convention is to add users is when we need different functional permissions for different things and there are good cut points to allow granting least privilege (mostly to mitigate security exploits / bugs).
For example, if we had a separate GAE service connecting to the same DB for a slightly different purpose (e.g. different subset of tables), another SQL user would probably make sense.
I could see an argument for a dev-writer user to allow it to evolve separately of workbench, and for logging purposes on the off-chance this surfaces somewhere useful.
Going for something like one user per developer I think would be a pain to maintain and would not gain us much.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1277,6 +1277,8 @@ def write_db_creds_file(project, cdr_db_name, root_password, workbench_password)
       db_creds_file.puts "MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=#{root_password}"
       db_creds_file.puts "WORKBENCH_DB_USER=workbench"
       db_creds_file.puts "WORKBENCH_DB_PASSWORD=#{workbench_password}"
+      db_creds_file.puts "DEV_READONLY_DB_USER=dev-readonly"

nodes.bodyText: nit: I think this would be a bit more readable if the CREATE/PASSWORD/GRANT statements were grouped by user instead of by statement type.
I'd rather keep all the user initialization first before executing any other GRANT statements
If I were looking at the help text quickly, I'd probably be looking for an option like --read-only or --access=read-only rather than --db-user (which is a bit of an implementation detail).

nodes.bodyText:
I added more to the flag doc. The problem with that approach is that we have existing functionality which supports signing in as --root instead. So the --readonly proposal means we now have mutually exclusive flags with confusing interactions, since the implementations are all driven by the database user e.g. --readonly, --db-user or , --readonly and --root
I'd prefer to leave this general and add documentation. Also - I feel readonly should be the default, so I don't like it as a flag. --no-readonly maybe (suffers from same issues).

nodes.bodyText: Please break this into three assignments, one on each line, or make a method that outputs an array of random passwords so it's like root_password, workbench_password, readonly_password = *random_passwords(3). I stared at it for a good minute before I realized it was a multi-assignment.
